snippet.title: Caulfield North homes amass $387 million in 12 months - realestate.com.au
snippet.content:
sold for $3.005 million in May.
Caulfield North has been revealed as the top spot for property spending in the region, with more than $380 million spent on its homes in the past year. A staggering $1.77 billion was spent on homes in the Caulfield Glen Eira area in the 12 months to April, new CoreLogic data shows. The top total value of sales was in Caulfield North, at $387 million. Hocking Stuart Caulfield and Elsternwick director Marshall Rushford said the market there had performed well in the past year. "There have been some amazing results," he said. "We are finding anything with a land component to it is selling really well." Mr Rushford pointed to the auction sale of a circa-1906 home on more than 1000sq m at , in May. "We had three to four bidders and it sold for $3,005,000," Mr Rushford said. "It was a magnificent home." Mr Rushford said Caulfield North homes were tightly held, so competition was strong. Infrastructure and facilities were also a key driver of the region's home sales, he said. "People see it as a very safe place to extend themselves and to buy into, because it has everything they need," he said. SEE SUBURB PROFILE:
sold for $1.84 million earlier in July.
Meanwhile, Carnegie amassed more than $294 million in property sales in the 12 months to April. Ray White Carnegie agent Josh Hommelhoff said the suburb's top end had seen strong price growth. "Family homes that are now selling for $1.8 million to $2 million were not too long ago getting $1.2 million to $1.5 million," he said. Mr Hommelhoff said a house at sold in July for $1.84 million. "We had 93 inspections over three weeks," he added. CoreLogic figures show property sales in Caulfield South topped $279 million in the 12 months to April, Elsternwick saw more than $240 million, and Murrumbeena totalled more than $166 million. In the same period Ormond amassed more than $164 million in total sales, Caulfield $111 million, Glen Huntly $76 million, Ripponlea $28 million, and Caulfield East $21 million. SEE SUBURB PROFILE:
